awd_titl_txt: Antarctic and Arctic Data Consortium (a2dc) Research Coordination Network: Scientific Research Support and Data Services for the Polar Community
awd_abstract_narration: The Antarctic & Arctic Data Consortium (a2dc) was established in spring 2013 as a grass-roots initiative to help improve the visibility of data resources for the polar geoscience community through a modest joint marketing effort at national meetings and on the web. Out of this self-organizing effort came the recognition that while each data facility serves a different segment of the polar community, improved coordination and better integration of our data resources would significantly benefit the broad and multi-disciplinary community engaged in polar science. Up to date, there has been little interaction or coordination between polar data facilities, yet much is to be gained by sharing experiences, technological approaches and leveraging existing solutions. The project aims at formalizing and enhancing the coordination of a2dc members through the coordination of a network that will bring the data facilities together on an annual basis. This will support new coordinated outreach to the science community to help researchers identify and use the services that are available to them and for the centers to ensure they are more effectively serving the widest possible audience, including international stakeholders.

por.por_cntn:
Overall Goal:

The Antarctic & Arctic Data Consortium (a2dc) was established in spring 2013 as a grass-roots initiative to help improve the visibility of data resources for the polar geoscience community through a modest joint marketing effort at national meetings and on the web. Out of this self-organizing effort came the recognition that while each data facility serves a different segment of the polar community, improved coordination and better integration of our data resources would significantly benefit the broad and multi-disciplinary community engaged in polar science. While we share many common goals and challenges, historically there had been little interaction or coordination between polar data facilities, yet much is to be gained by sharing experiences, technological approaches and leveraging existing solutions. The overall goal of this project was to formalize and enhance the coordination of a2dc members through workshops, outreach and engagement at AGU Fall Meetings, and identifying other mechanisms to better serve and support the polar science community.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The actual funding amount for the a2dc RCN was reduced significantly from the original proposal (we received less than 25% of the requested amount, and notably no funding support for the project CoPIs), and in turn the scope of work had to be altered. Despite this scaling back, we were committed to improve coordination among the a2dc facilities, and the effort was very successful. This project for the first time formalized the consortium and provided funding for an annual meeting and related activities, most prominently having a booth and community outreach efforts at numerous AGU Fall Meetings.

Our largest community outreach effort was the popular annual a2dc calendar, which the University of Minnesota Polar Geospatial Center (PGC) produced the first three years (2013, 2014, 2015). In 2016 funding for the calendar shifted to the a2dc project. In 2017 we staffed a booth at AGU, and representatives from many of the a2dc facilities volunteered for time slots. The 2018 and 2019 AGU booth was staffed primarily by PGC staff and students. This outreach was an outstanding way to spread the word to the community (veteran and new researchers alike), and to broaden interest and understanding of the a2dc member organizations and our missions. With a modest investment, the a2dc RCN augmented the existing infrastructure and expertise of all the centers to increase the visibility and effectiveness of all the facilities.

 

Broader Impacts:

The a2dc RCN helped play a role in demonstrating and identifying concrete ways facilities serve their communities, relate and support one another and work with NSF.  The impact was especially profound for students at the graduate, undergraduate, and even secondary levels (and their teachers), as the simplification of data discovery, visualization, and comparison will allow people with less training to interact with polar science data in a meaningful way. These tools serve a meaningful and impactful role in facilitating the communication of scientific findings, including to policymakers and the public at large.
